I'm just writing this review to ask people to stop giving it negative reviews with messages about how they're disapointed about what happened to the Half-Life franchise. If you don't like the game than give it a negative review, if you don't like how Valve just pretty much fucked up what could have possibly been one of the top greatest video game franchises ever than write a blog about it online or somewhere else that isn't in the form of hurting this games ratings on Steam. New people will see the negative reviews and assume it's a bad game and decide not to buy it which will than in turn hurt the franchise even more. So to the people who post negative reviews but talk about how Valve fucked up your favourite franchise you're essentially making the situation worse, to give an analogy you're pouring gasoline on a fire with the intent to put it out and you need to stop.

The vastness of the Combineâ€™s power, the futility of our struggle, blossomed briefly in my awareness. I saw everything.

Enough time has passed that few remember me, or what I was saying when last I spoke, or what precisely we hoped to accomplish. At this point, the resistance will have failed or succeeded, no thanks to me. Old friends have been silenced, or fallen by the wayside. I no longer know or recognize most members of the research team, though I believe the spirit of rebellion still persists. I expect you know better than I the appropriate course of action, and I leave you to it. Expect no further correspondence from me regarding these matters; this is my final episode.

Great prequel to Half Life 3. Makes a lot more sense how Half Life 3 started.

I was a bit nervous going into this game after Episode 1, because I wasn't sure if it'd be able to come up with enough new mechanics and narrative elements to keep the series fresh. I was very pleasantly surprised in that HL2E2 matches its predecessor pretty much evenly. There was no shortage of thrilling moments or mildly challenging puzzles and the pacing of all of the chapters is excellent. 

It's a travesty that this is where the story seems to have ended because there seems to be a huge potential for crossover with Aperture and exploration of the world left at the end of HL2E2. I guess I'll just cross my fingers and keep waiting!
Half-Life 2 gameplay, but with as much variety as the original game. Picks up after Episode One in a timely manner. Arguably better than the first game.

Well... I just finished the trilogy, and it deserves an upvote, I don't agree with review bombing. Such masterpiece must be upvoted. 

This game is great, well-written, a masterpiece. This upvote goes for the team who created the HL 2 series. I didn't want to touch this last epÃ¬sode because I knew that I'll face a void. Maybe Valve is waiting for their new engine, just like the jump they did from HL to HL2, but the last news are depressing. Maybe we will never see Ep. 3, maybe we will. 
A bitter ending, this comunity hungers for more, but not for quantity, hungers for quality. Not even actual AAA titles are rich as this game. The story is prefectly written, it's like you live the tale, you laugh, your blood boils, and the feels throw never ending punches.

Afiter such cliffhanger, and Valve mediocricy with their games such as TF2 (I used to play it but now their official stuff is pretty dead), CS GO (I play it but *HAX INTENSIFIES*), I don't expect the same level as quality as they did with the HL franchise, they could add crates or any other bs (in such incident, yes review bombing is the solution, that'd be a disgusting move from Valve), or even the launch of a new HL episode. Valve is not looking for quality, they are looking for skins, hats, cosmetics, etc... I truly lost my faith in Valve.

But still, I'd recommend this game, and not only the game but the entire damn series. I know Valve is acting like a douche, but this game deservers praise! I'll remember this game forever and I will keep it as an example of true quality.

Good game. Commentary is also fascinating. Loved hearing about how the various elements were lovingly built to create a coherent and innovative experience. So easy to take for granted how much Valve put into this game.  
Love: 
- the characters
- the drama and sense of urgency
- the humour
- the great core gameplay

Minor niggles:
- gameplay is beginning to feel tired. By the time I reached the latter part of the game I was thinking "I've seen this all before" (that judgment might be partially to do with the fact I played HL2, HL2: EP1 and HL2: EP2 back-to-back) 
- Not a fan of the driving bits, which feel clumsy to me (or revealed my clumsiness, take your pick)

What would I like from HL2: EP3?

1. More of the great story, characters, humour
2. Some new and interesting mechanic to help enliven the gameplay
3. The original voice acting cast and writers to return
4. A conclusion fitting of it's predecessors

Valve, if you want ideas on where to go with HL2: EP3, I'd love to contribute. 

HL2: EP2 is a classic and I love it. And like so many others, I want more. Fingers crossed.
